evaluation_methodology: Each aphorism was evaluated by comparing all available English translations against the German original (Gutenberg). Scores assess philosophical fidelity (preservation of concepts/terms), tonal preservation (Nietzsche's ironic/provocative voice), and interpretive liberty (1=literal, 10=heavily interpreted). Aphorisms with missing or corrupted texts (<20 chars) in certain translations are noted.

analyses.german_summary: On why the mightiest men bowed before the saint - recognizing the 'will to power' in ascetic self-conquest
analyses.key_issue: Kaufmann's text appears corrupted/misaligned (discusses coldness/ice instead of the saint). Norman's text is MISSING. Hollingdale preserves 'Wille zur Macht' and the questioning structure excellently.

analyses.german_summary: Comparing Old Testament grandeur to New Testament 'rococo' - calling their combination a 'sin against the spirit'
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern's text appears misaligned (discussing Pascal and curiosity instead). Key term 'Sünde wider den Geist' well-preserved by most. 'Rokoko des Geschmacks' rendered consistently as 'rococo of taste'.

analyses.german_summary: Why atheism today? God as father/judge refuted, but religious instinct grows while rejecting theism
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern's text bleeds into the next aphorism (54). The key diagnostic tone of 'fragend, hinhorchend' (asking, listening) is variously rendered. Hollingdale preserves the investigative quality best.

analyses.german_summary: Modern philosophy's attack on the soul-concept since Descartes, the 'I think' problem, Vedanta parallel
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern MISSING. Critical term 'Attentat' (assassination attempt) on the soul-concept preserved by all. 'Vedanta-Philosophie' reference maintained. Subtle point about anti-Christian but not anti-religious nature of modern philosophy well-captured.

analyses.german_summary: The great ladder of religious cruelty: human sacrifice, then instinct-sacrifice, finally God-sacrifice for nothingness
analyses.key_issue: Key phrase 'Für das Nichts Gott opfern' (sacrificing God for nothingness) preserved by all. Kaufmann captures the escalating rhetorical force exceptionally. The 'Tiberius in the Mithras grotto' historical reference maintained.

analyses.german_summary: The world-affirming ideal vs. Schopenhauer's pessimism - eternal recurrence ('da capo'), circulus vitiosus deus
analyses.key_issue: Central to Nietzsche's eternal recurrence doctrine. 'Da capo' musical term preserved. 'Circulus vitiosus deus' kept in Latin. Kaufmann's footnotes add scholarly context. Norman's text is truncated.

analyses.german_summary: As spiritual vision grows, our world deepens - 'God' and 'sin' may become like child's toys to the eternal child
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern's text bleeds into aphorism 58. The beautiful metaphor of 'ewiges Kind' (eternal child) well-preserved. The idea of God/sin as child's toys captures Nietzsche's developmental view of concepts.

analyses.german_summary: Religious life requires leisure/idleness - modern industriousness prepares for 'unbelief'
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern MISSING. Long meditation on religion and social class. Key insight: 'Müssiggang mit gutem Gewissen' (leisure with good conscience) as aristocratic prerequisite for religious depth.

analyses.german_summary: Human superficiality as wisdom - piety as ultimate falsification, beautifying humanity through art/surface
analyses.key_issue: Kaufmann text is EMPTY (0 chars). Key term 'homines religiosi' preserved in Latin. The paradox of piety as 'most consistent falsification' artfully rendered by remaining translators.

analyses.german_summary: To love man for God's sake - the noblest feeling; whoever first felt this 'flew highest and erred most beautifully'
analyses.key_issue: Beautiful aphorism on sanctified love. The phrase 'am schönsten sich verirrt hat' (got lost most beautifully) is poetically crucial - Hollingdale's 'gone the most beautifully astray' captures it best.

analyses.german_summary: The philosopher using religion for 'Züchtung' (breeding/cultivation) - Brahmins as example of philosopher-priests
analyses.key_issue: Controversial 'Züchtung' term: Kaufmann uses 'cultivation/breeding', Hollingdale 'breeding/education'. The political implications of philosopher using religion as tool for human development. Norman's text truncated.

analyses.german_summary: Danger when religions rule sovereignly - they preserve too much that should perish, keeping 'man' at lower level
analyses.key_issue: Critical passage on religion's preservation of 'failures'. Key phrase 'das noch nicht festgestellte Thier' (the not-yet-determined animal) preserved. Norman's text severely truncated.

analyses.german_summary: A true teacher takes all things seriously only in relation to students - even himself
analyses.key_issue: Short but incisive. 'Von Grund aus' (from the ground up / through and through) variously rendered. The self-deprecating twist ('even himself') preserved by all.

analyses.german_summary: 'Knowledge for its own sake' as morality's last snare - becoming entangled again
analyses.key_issue: Classic Nietzschean critique of disinterested knowledge. 'Fallstrick' (snare/trap) consistently rendered. The implication that pure knowledge is still a moral value well-captured.

analyses.german_summary: The charm of knowledge includes overcoming shame; 65a: we are most dishonest to our god - he may not sin
analyses.key_issue: Two-part aphorism (65 and 65a). The paradox in 65a - dishonesty toward God by not allowing him to sin - subtly preserved. Zimmern's text slightly garbled.

analyses.german_summary: The inclination to debase oneself could be the shame of a god among men
analyses.key_issue: Key term 'Scham' variously as 'shame', 'modesty', 'diffidence', 'self-effacement'. Hollingdale's 'self-effacement' captures the divine humility implication elegantly.

analyses.german_summary: Love for one is barbarism - practiced at expense of others; even love of God
analyses.key_issue: Kaufmann includes extensive footnote explaining numbering issues. The provocative inclusion of divine love in the critique ('Auch die Liebe zu Gott') preserved by all.

analyses.german_summary: Memory says 'I did that' - pride says impossible - eventually memory yields
analyses.key_issue: Famous proto-Freudian aphorism on repression. All translations capture the psychological mechanism perfectly. 'Unerbittlich' (inexorable/adamant) and final yielding well-rendered.

analyses.german_summary: One has watched life badly if not seeing the hand that considerately kills
analyses.key_issue: 'Schonende Weise' (considerate/gentle manner) variously rendered. The paradox of gentle killing well-preserved. Norman's 'ever so gently' adds interpretive flair.

analyses.german_summary: If one has character, one has a typical experience that always recurs
analyses.key_issue: Norman MISSING. Simple but profound observation on character and fate. 'Typisches Erlebniss' well-rendered as 'typical experience'.

analyses.german_summary: The sage as astronomer: as long as stars are 'above you', you lack the eye of knowledge
analyses.key_issue: Titled aphorism. The critical point about overcoming the 'above' relation to stars/cosmos preserved. 'Blick des Erkennenden' variously as 'eye of knowledge/discerning'.

analyses.german_summary: Not the strength but duration of high feelings makes high men
analyses.key_issue: Elegant aphorism, very literal translations work best. Faber's 'great man/great feelings' changes 'hohen' (high) to 'great', slightly altering meaning.

analyses.german_summary: Whoever reaches his ideal transcends it; 73a: Some peacocks hide their tail and call it pride
analyses.key_issue: Two-part aphorism. 73a's peacock metaphor for false modesty excellently captured. Kaufmann's 'eo ipso' in 73 adds scholarly Latin flourish matching Nietzsche's style.

analyses.german_summary: A genius is unbearable without gratitude and cleanliness
analyses.key_issue: Kaufmann adds extensive footnote comparing to Freud. 'Genie' and 'Reinlichkeit' (cleanliness/purity) consistently rendered. Zimmern's 'purity' slightly spiritualizes the concrete 'cleanliness'.

analyses.german_summary: The degree and kind of sexuality reaches into the highest pinnacle of one's spirit
analyses.key_issue: Proto-Freudian observation. 'Geschlechtlichkeit' as 'sexuality' preserved. Zimmern's 'sensuality' slightly shifts from the more directly sexual German term.

analyses.german_summary: Under peaceful conditions the warlike man attacks himself
analyses.key_issue: Faber's 'trips over himself' significantly weakens the more violent 'fällt über sich selber her' (attacks/falls upon himself). Most preserve the self-directed aggression.

analyses.german_summary: With principles we tyrannize/justify/honor/hide our habits - two with same principles may want different things
analyses.key_issue: Five-fold use of principles preserved. The psychological insight about principles serving various functions well-captured. 'Grund-Verschiedenes' (fundamentally different) consistently rendered.

analyses.german_summary: Whoever despises himself still respects himself as one who despises
analyses.key_issue: Perfect paradox. All translations capture the reflexive structure. Faber adds footnote asterisk. The self-referential logic ('Verächter') preserved excellently.

analyses.german_summary: A soul that knows it is loved but doesn't love reveals its sediment - the bottom rises
analyses.key_issue: Norman's text is WRONG - it repeats aphorism 70 content about character. 'Bodensatz' (sediment/dregs) metaphor for psychological depths preserved by others.

analyses.german_summary: What becomes clear ceases to concern us - what did 'Know thyself' mean? Become objective?
analyses.key_issue: Hollingdale's text bleeds into 81. Reference to Delphic oracle's 'Know thyself' and ironic suggestion about Socrates preserved. Multiple dashes maintain Nietzsche's questioning rhythm.

analyses.german_summary: Terrible to die of thirst at sea - must you salt your truth so heavily?
analyses.key_issue: Hollingdale and Zimmern MISSING (merged with 80). Powerful metaphor about truth needing to remain drinkable/useful. 'Salzen' (salt) as making truth unpalatable preserved.

analyses.german_summary: 'Pity for all' would be hardness and tyranny toward you, neighbor
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern MISSING (merged with 83). Anti-pity theme consistent with Nietzsche's broader critique. 'Mein Herr Nachbar' address preserved. Faber's 'chastise and tyrannize yourself' slightly shifts meaning.

analyses.german_summary: Instinct: when the house burns, one forgets lunch - but retrieves it from the ashes
analyses.key_issue: Zimmern has WRONG content (aphorism 82's pity text). Dark humor about instinct's persistence through crisis. 'Auf der Asche nachholen' (retrieve from ashes) well-captured.

analyses.german_summary: Woman learns to hate as she unlearns to charm
analyses.key_issue: Faber's text bleeds into 85. Controversial gender observation. 'Bezaubern/verlernt' (charm/unlearns) structure preserved. Hollingdale captures 'how to' construction elegantly.

analyses.german_summary: Same affects in man and woman differ in tempo - hence eternal misunderstanding
analyses.key_issue: Faber and Zimmern MISSING. Musical metaphor 'Tempo' (same German/English) key to understanding. The psychological insight about timing preserved.

analyses.german_summary: Behind all personal vanity, women have impersonal contempt for 'woman'
analyses.key_issue: Quotation marks around 'Weib' (woman) crucial - contempt for the concept/category. Distinction between personal/impersonal well-preserved.

analyses.german_summary: Bound heart, free spirit: bind your heart and give your spirit many liberties - but no one believes unless they know
analyses.key_issue: Titled aphorism on discipline. 'Gebunden Herz, freier Geist' title preserved. The self-referential 'I have said that once before' metanarrative captured.

analyses.german_summary: One begins to mistrust very clever people when they become embarrassed
analyses.key_issue: Simple and literal works best. 'Verlegen' as 'embarrassed' consistently rendered. The psychological insight about cleverness and vulnerability preserved.

analyses.german_summary: Terrible experiences raise the question whether the one experiencing them isn't something terrible
analyses.key_issue: Norman and Faber texts bleed into 90/91. The dark suggestion about experience and character preserved. 'Fürchterlich' (terrible/dreadful) key word.

analyses.german_summary: Heavy, melancholy people become lighter through hatred and love - they surface temporarily
analyses.key_issue: Norman and Faber MISSING. Paradox: what weighs others down lightens the heavy-hearted. 'Schwermüthig' as 'melancholy/heavy-spirited' preserved.

analyses.german_summary: So cold, so icy one burns fingers - yet some think he glows
analyses.key_issue: Kaufmann, Norman, Faber MISSING. Paradox of cold appearing hot preserved by Hollingdale and Zimmern. Note: This aphorism appears misplaced in Kaufmann's edition (as 51).

analyses.german_summary: Who has not sacrificed himself for his good reputation?
analyses.key_issue: Rhetorical question structure preserved. Faber's 'maintained his good reputation by sacrificing himself' slightly more interpretive. The irony about self-sacrifice for appearances captured.

analyses.german_summary: In affability there is no hatred of men, but for that reason too much contempt
analyses.key_issue: 'Leutseligkeit' as 'affability/geniality' preserved. The paradox: no hatred implies contempt. Faber's abbreviated version loses some force.

analyses.german_summary: Man's maturity: rediscovering the seriousness one had as a child at play
analyses.key_issue: Famous aphorism on play and maturity. 'Ernst' (seriousness) and 'Spiel' (play) contrast preserved. Norman's 'towards play' slightly alters the 'beim Spiel' (at play).

analyses.german_summary: Being ashamed of immorality is a step toward being ashamed of morality
analyses.key_issue: Key Nietzschean progression: immorality-shame leads to morality-shame. Ladder/staircase metaphor ('Stufe auf der Treppe') preserved. Beyond good and evil theme epitomized.

analyses.german_summary: Depart from life like Odysseus from Nausicaa - blessing rather than in love
analyses.key_issue: Beautiful classical reference. 'Segnend' (blessing) vs 'verliebt' (in love) contrast key. Zimmern uses 'Ulysses' (Latin) vs others' 'Odysseus' (Greek).

analyses.german_summary: A great man? I always see only the actor of his own ideal
analyses.key_issue: 'Schauspieler' (actor/play-actor) central metaphor. The skepticism about greatness as performance preserved. Question format maintained.

analyses.german_summary: If we train our conscience, it kisses us while it bites
analyses.key_issue: 'Dressirt' (trains/disciplines) and the kiss-while-biting image preserved. Faber's 'teach our conscience to do tricks' adds interpretive element.

analyses.german_summary: The disappointed one speaks: 'I listened for echo and heard only praise'
analyses.key_issue: Titled aphorism. The irony: expecting echo (honest response), receiving only praise (flattery). 'Enttäuschte' as 'disappointed one' preserved. Subtle critique of intellectual dishonesty.

analyses.german_summary: We all pose as simpler than we are before ourselves - resting from our fellow men
analyses.key_issue: Norman's text is WRONG - completely different content about scholars and skepticism (appears to be from later chapter). 'Einfältiger' (simpler) and 'ausruhen' (rest) key terms preserved by others.

key_observations: Hollingdale provides the most consistently faithful translations with excellent tonal preservation
Kaufmann's translations are strong but contain several misaligned/missing aphorisms in this section
Norman's edition has multiple alignment issues where wrong content appears under aphorism numbers
Zimmern (1906) shows age but maintains dignity; some aphorisms merged with neighbors
Faber balances accessibility with fidelity but occasionally over-interprets
The 'Epigrams and Interludes' section (63-100) contains many short, punchy aphorisms where literal translation excels
Key Nietzschean terms (Wille zur Macht, da capo, circulus vitiosus deus) consistently preserved in Latin/original
Proto-Freudian psychological insights (68, 75) well-captured across translations
